overview: How to take a claim to an employment tribunal - the claim form, what happens at a hearing, and how to appeal if you lose your case
title: Take your employer to an employment tribunal

table.body:
You can take your employer to an employment tribunal if you think they've treated you unfairly, or broken the law.

The tribunal is independent, and could order the employer to pay you compensation if you win your case.

%You usually have to apply to the tribunal within 3 months of your employment ending, or the problem happening at work.%

##What cases the tribunal can deal with

The tribunal can deal with a wide range of claims, eg:

- unfair dismissal
- discrimination
- unfair deductions from your pay

##Before you go to the tribunal

Before you go the tribunal, see if there is another way to solve the problem - eg using a grievance procedure.

Phone Acas (Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service) for help and advice on how to solve the problem.

$C **Acas**  
08457 474 747 $C

##Apply to the tribunal

To apply to the tribunal, fill in a claim form:

$D [Download 'Employment tribunals claim form' (PDF, 1024KB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/global/forms/tribunals/employment/ET1.pdf "Download 'Employment tribunals claim form (PDF, 1024KB)'"){:rel="external"} $D
$D [Download 'Making a claim to an employment tribunal - guidance notes' (PDF, 244KB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/guidance/courts-and-tribunals/tribunals/employment/forms/10_516_MCTS_Employment_April10_web.pdf "Making a claim to an employment tribunal - guidance notes"){:rel="external"} $D

You can submit the form online or post it to your [local employment tribunal office.](http://www.justice.gov.uk/tribunals/employment/venues "local employment tribunal office"){:rel="external"}

##Get help making a claim

You may want to get [legal help or advice](http://legaladviserfinder.justice.gov.uk/AdviserSearch.do "Find a legal adviser"){:rel="external"} before you make your claim.

Your trade union may be able to pay for a solicitor.

The [Equality and Human Rights Commission](http://www.equalityhumanrights.com/about-us/advice-from-our-helpline "Equality and Human Rights Commission"){:rel="external"} can help if your claim is about discrimination.

For general guidance on how the process works, call the employment tribunal enquiry line. Note that they **cannot** give legal advice.

$C **Employment Tribunal public enquiry line**  
**Telephone:** 08457 959 775  
**Minicom:** 0845 757 3722 $C

##If you're in Northern Ireland

If you live in Northern Ireland, you need to appeal to the [Office of Industrial Tribunals and the Fair Employment Tribunal.](http://www.employmenttribunalsni.co.uk/ "Office of Industrial Tribunals and the Fair Employment Tribunal"){:rel="external"}

*[Acas]: Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service
table.title: Taking a case to an employment tribunal

table.body:
Someone from Acas (Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service) may contact you to see if you can solve the problem without going to a tribunal.

This is a free service and anything you say to Acas will be confidential.

##If the employer doesn't respond to your claim

The employer usually has to respond to your claim, to give their side of the case, within 28 days of getting your claim form.

If they don't reply, an employment judge may decide on your case without you having to go to a hearing.

##If the employer responds to your claim

If your employer does respond, there will be a hearing to decide on your case.

You may be asked to go to a meeting with the judge to decide on:

- the date and time of the hearing
- how long the hearing should take
- other issues about your case

##Getting ready for a hearing

Contact the tribunal office if you have any problems, eg:

- getting information from the employer
- asking a witness to come to your hearing

You'll get a letter giving you details of the hearing, where the tribunal will make a final decision - or 'judgment' - on your case.
table.title: After you send your claim

table.body:
When you go to the tribunal hearing, take the documents you're using to support your case.

You can take a colleague with you if you want, but they can't speak for you or ask questions. You are both entitled to paid time off work for this.

Cases are normally held in the [employment tribunal office](http://www.justice.gov.uk/tribunals/employment/venues "employment tribunal office"){:rel="external"} closest to place where you worked.

##What happens at the hearing

You (or your representative) and the employer put your cases to a panel or a judge, and answer questions.

You will normally give evidence first, unless your case is about unfair dismissal.

^You normally get the tribunal’s decision - or 'judgment' - on the day, but it may be sent in the post a few days after the hearing.^

You can't claim for expenses for going to the hearing.
table.title: Going to a tribunal hearing

table.body:
If you win your case, the tribunal can order your employer to:

* pay you compensation
* improve your working conditions
* give you your job back, if appropriate

If you are given compensation the amount you get depends on:

* the type of case
* your age, length of service, and salary

Usually there are set limits to the amount you can get. However, in cases of discrimination, there is no limit.

If your employer is ordered to re-employ you and doesn't, or fails to obey any other order, the tribunal can force them to pay you extra compensation.

##If your employer doesn't pay

If you don't get your payment, first contact your employer to find out why. 

If they still don't pay, you can force them to.

You may not be able to do this if the employer has, or is about to, appeal.

###If you're in England or Wales

Ask the local county court to send an enforcement officer to get the money from your employer. This costs £40.

To do this, fill in an [application to enforce an award](http://hmctsformfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=552 "N322A - Application to enforce an award form"){:rel="external"} form, using the [guidance notes](http://hmctsformfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=2363 "guidance for completing form N322A"){:rel="external"} to help you.

Send this, with copy of the tribunal's decision, to your [local county court.](http://hmctscourtfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/ "Find your local court"){:rel="external"}

You can also use the Fast Track scheme to send a High Court Enforcement Officer - similar to a bailiff - to demand payment from your employer.

This costs £60, which you get back from the employer when they pay.

To use this service, fill in the [Employment Tribunal Fast Track Enforcement form.](http://hmctsformfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetLeaflet.do?court_leaflets_id=2393 "Employment Tribunal Fast Track Enforcement Form"){:rel="external"}

Send it to the address on the form.

###If you're in Scotland

Write to the office that heard from your case, asking for an 'extract of the judgement'. A Sheriff Officer can use this to force the employer to pay.

##Redundancy payments

If you're due a redundancy payment and your employer hasn't paid it, call the Redundancy Payments Helpline.

$C **Redundancy Payments Helpline**  
0845 145 0004 $C
table.title: If you win your case

table.body:
If you lose your case, you may be able to:

- ask the tribunal to look at the case again
- appeal to the Employment Appeal Tribunal

##Ask the tribunal to review the decision or judgment

You need to write to the tribunal office within 14 days of getting the decision, saying why you want it to be reviewed.

You also need to give good reasons for asking for a review, eg:

- the tribunal made a mistake in the way it reached its decision
- you weren't told about the hearing, or weren't at the hearing
- new evidence has turned up since the hearing

Send the form to the [tribunal office.](http://www.justice.gov.uk/tribunals/employment/venues "tribunal office"){:rel="external"}

##Appeal to the Employment Appeal Tribunal

You can also appeal if you think the tribunal made a legal mistake.

To do this, fill in a notice of appeal form:

$D [Download 'Notice of appeal form' (PDF, 80KB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/global/forms/tribunals/emp-appeals/Form1NoticeOfAppeal.pdf "Download 'Notice of appeal form' (PDF, 80KB)") $D

Say why you think the decision was legally wrong or unreasonable.

Send the form to the appropriate address below, along with copies of:

- your original claim form
- the employer's response
- the tribunal's decision, and the written reasons for it

Ask the tribunal to send you written reasons, if you don't already have them.

%You usually need to apply within 42 days of receiving the decision or the written reasons.%
